intro: Galium hierochuntinum var. papillosum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, ascending stems that are often covered in fine, white hairs. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often have a hairy texture, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This variant is native to specific regions in Europe and is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
